Title.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel surgical approach for treating these conditions.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either the intervention or standard care.

Participants.evidence: Twenty-three patients with subtrochanteric aseptic nonunions, aged under 60 years, and with 2.0 to 5.0 cm shortening were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved femoral condylar skeletal traction, one-stage lengthening up to 4 cm, static locked nail stabilization, and corticocancellous bone grafting.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel surgical approach for treating these conditions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the union rate, assessed over a minimum follow-up of 1.2 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-three patients with subtrochanteric aseptic nonunions, aged under 60 years, and with 2.0 to 5.0 cm shortening were enrolled.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group achieved a 100% union rate (21/21) with a median union period of 4.0 months (range, 3.5–11 months).
